name: Esha Jain
reviewBody: The actual quality of the book is phenomenal. I was surprised how great of a condition the book was in. I bought this book because a friend of mine recommended it. I checked the reviews on Amazon and was convinced to buy this. I am not a reader, as a matter of fact, I do not like reading. But after reading the first law, I couldn't stop reading. This book has made me reflect on who I am, how I behave, react, and think. It is teaching me how to be a better person and has changed me in great ways! I highly recommend this book to everyone.

name: bumandy
reviewTitles: Packed full of wisdom throughout the ages. Both unabridged and abridged editions are excellent
reviewBody: "The 48 Laws of Power" was a wake-up call for me. It reminded me of Machiavell's "The Prince" which I read in high school. However, I thought "The Prince" had no relevance to my life since I did not need to decide whether or not to chop the head off a defeated king.Robert Greene's book helped to make the connection between Machiavelli's principles and methods and what I have experienced in my professional career. While nearly everyone claims to be straightforward and honest, some are adept at maneuvering themselves into advantageous positions. "The 48 Laws" explains the many tools these individuals use to increase their power, usually at the expense of yours. I have found the most valuable books to help me learn about life through the experiences of others and this book is packed full of wisdom throughout the ages.Several of the 48 laws that were insightful to me were:Law 1 - Never outshine the masterLaw 4 - Always say less than necessaryLaw 9 - Win through your actions, never through argumentLaw 16 - Use absence to increase respect and honorLaw 20 - Do not commit to anyoneLaw 29 - Plan all the way to the endLaw 38 - Think as you like but behave like othersLaw 46 - Never appear too perfectLaw 48 - Assume formlesslessA few of these may sound obivious, silly, puzzling. However, there are plenty of historical examples to explain each law (in the form of "observance of the law", "violation of the law", and "reversals"). I may use a few of the laws in the future but mostly, I will be aware of the laws to watch my back.Both the unabridged and abridged versions are excellent - 'Machiavelli's ¨'The Prince¨ on steroids. If you have the time, go with the unabridged edition because it has many more historical examples. However, if you are time constrained, the abridged version is terrific as well.I first listened to the abridged version and found it to have many pearls of wisdom. As the author suggests, I identified many examples of the laws in my professional and academic career. I wished I had read (or listened) to this book earlier in my youth.I then listened to the unabridged version because I was interested in the full text and it did not disappoint with many more historical examples - ¨the wise learn from the mistakes of others.¨
postDate: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on July 16, 2015

reviewBody: Affordable and very good book for feeding the brain

name: Peter Garcia
reviewBody: I'm the type who, "buys me now, reads me later..." type of book buyer. I first tried to read Robert Greene's book some time back, I couldn't get into it. So I put it to the side for the time being....A) In 2012 I began reading "Sun Tzu For Success" by Gerald Michaelson and Steven Michaelson. As a result my eyes were opened to the possibilities in how to see the big picture in the success planning. As well as how thinking in proactive mode can produce stronger results than reaction thinking like most of us would do.B) So when I finally read "48 Laws", it was like life-lessons reading in how to get along with people. Or how immature people will behave toward you. Which I never understood since most of us know about morals, ethics and family-values in our civilized society of the 21st century.C) The biggest chapter for me was Law#24; "Play the Perfect Courtier". It's how to play internal politics either at work or in social groups. Wow!, what an eye opener.D) Or how about Law#46: "Never Appear Too Perfect". Your efforts to be ambitious, successful or even just plain charming can create envy and people hating you for no reason but for you being at your best.E) Another is Law#18:"Do Not Build Fortresses to Protect Yourself-Isolation is Dangerous" It's what happens when you are work alone and cut yourself off. You lose "being out of the loop" from very important information to dominate from.F) Even if you are a person of high character and a good person. Your friends and working peers won't always see the world the way you do. So protect yourself from these bad people.F) SO YOU MUST BUY THIS BOOK!... IT'S TODAY'S BIBLE!So now I'm reading "The New Boss" by Peter Fischer. "How To Survive the First 100 Days" whether starting a new job or new to a group. I'm using "48 Laws" like a reference book for when I observe a behavior and ask why are they?... Combined I stand a better chance to not just survive but thrive in my ever changing environments!Enjoy!
postDate: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on August 13, 2012

name: Brian V.
reviewTitles: A Must Read for People With a Purpose
reviewBody: Downloaded this book at the suggestion of one of my students last night. Really like it. Caught me off guard as it is written in a similar style(in my opinion) as the "Art of War" (one of my favorites) is written in. Based on the author's bio was expecting something more trendy, but once I went back and read the preface the style made sense in that he is cherry picking some of the best ideas about power over the last 3000 years - not just pop-culture stuff.What I really liked about it is a reader can just pick off one of the laws per day, and dive as deep into each as one wants. Any one of the 48 can increase someone's awareness, an help them better achieve their purpose. Nice to have a book that has more than just one main idea and 155 pages of dribble surrounding it (like most bestselling business books).In summary, this is going on my informal book recommendation list. I think it is one of those few books that I have seen that is interesting enough to actually make time to read in a few days, but will take a life to master. Wish I had this book when I was in my 20's.Best,Brian Vanderjack, PMP, MBA Recent HBR Linkedin "Top Contributor" (out of 500,000 member community) Email: BVanderjac@Gmail.com (put "48" in the subject and will read your replies) Linkedin: [...]Ps. FYI - There are about 1000 versions of the "Art of War," and their approaches to the material vary widely. If you are interested in checking it out, definitely skim a few of them at the library to find one that works for you before you invest in one.
postDate: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on May 29, 2014

name: Harvey Spector
reviewTitles: The best book I have ever read
reviewBody: I have read over 100 books on sales, business, and self help. This is my favorite. The amount of knowledge and value this book provides is unbelievable. Even if you do not plan on following the rules it is important that you at least understand them and can determine when other people are using them. At the end of the book you are left asking yourself "Am I a better or worse person after reading this". The author Robert Greene is the first to admit that if you view these laws as gospel and follow all of the laws to the full extreme you are borderline psychopathic. It is the reader's job to take these laws, learn from them, and use them in a positive way without negatively impacting your relationships with the people in your life.
postDate: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on May 31, 2021

name: matthew

name: C. J. Southern
reviewBody: I'm sure that many want power, fame, money, and all that goes with it but - in my opinion - if the ethical and social costs to achieve those things are too high then it's just not worth it.In that vein, if you're wanting a book that teaches how to achieve power (and all that goes with it) based on a foundation of honesty, integrity, and self-worth (etc) then this is not the book for you.It's my personal belief that anyone who follows the advice in this book will probably end up living a very shallow existance with few (if any) friends.The fact that so many have apparantly rated it so highly suggests to me that the world is definitely heading down the wrong path.I got about 4 or 5 chapters into it and just permanantly deleted it; my biggest regret is that I can neither get my money back nor the time I wasted reading even part of it.
postDate: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on December 21, 2022

name: Christian Pineda
reviewBody: I give this four stars mainly because I was bothered by formatting and the examples given in the book. The laws themselves are well thought out and backed up with examples, but nearly every anecdote in the book brings the reader back 500 years into a time that wasn't necessarily relatable. I give the author credit in the sense that history repeats itself and the examples are still valid, but it would have been nice to read a mix of contemporary and a mix of historical anecdotes. I just found the book a little bit slow given I was reading about kings and queens and wars the entire time. Power is a subject applicable to ALL domains, and I felt this book was a bit narrow.Also, I found it very distracting how the author includes one-off snippets between stories that are totally unrelated. It disrupts the flow of the book.All that said, this book is well worth the read. I just wouldn't suggest reading it like a normal book. This is one of those books you just have to pick up over and over again and read little snippets of.
postDate: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on June 22, 2022

name: Steve Wood
reviewBody: I remember a friend at work recommended reading this book. He was going to let me borrow it(I bought the Art of Seduction and planned on reading it before reading this) and I would let him borrow the Art of Seduction; a book exchange. Unfortunately, my friend was fired so I didn't get the chance to borrow the 48 Laws.I had remembered this, and went ahead and bought it. I thought it was better to read this first before the Art of Seduction. Before reading the 48 Laws, I began the Art of Seduction, but couldn't get into it.As soon as I began 48 Laws, I was intrigued. This was kind of book I was looking for. Because of my interest in the 48 Laws, I began the Art of Seduction again; reading these two books, side by side(not literally), I saw connections, and wanted to finish them; because of my curiosity, I wanted to see if these principles can be applied.I like the author's style of writing, explaining historical events, describing classical literary works; he would then explain observances and transgressions of these Laws, and how they can be interpreted.I really liked this book, and will come back to it again for another read.
postDate: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on February 6, 2015

name: will
reviewBody: This is an excellent book.Read this in light manner. Don't read it like it should be followed religiously.The power to extract the power from this book is how you read it. If read in the book in the right mindset, it can get you in the flow of universal in which the book talks about.However, if the reader is not emotional or mentally balanced the power will be out of their reach.Such is the way of Power.Do not underestimate the power of this book.This is an excellent book that needs to be read and read and then read some more.I have used the techniques offered in this book on how to gain power, and I have to admit, it works. Not only does most of the laws work, it s suppressing how easy it is to attain success and power.This is a book to be studied, not just read once. If you want to really get in touch with Power.Overall, excellent book. Some chapters are a little out there for me. Read what you like and leave the rest, s the best way to read this book.No pun intended, but this is a Powerful book.
postDate: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on March 10, 2013

name: Andrew
reviewBody: The reviews on whether this book is moral or not aren't relevant: Greene makes excellent use of historical examples in proving each law, and history is based on facts rather than morals. Each law has been historically demonstrated, and a plethora of laws are plainly visible in the world today. A fantastic read on the different manifestations of power, how those have come to pass in history, and how you can usurp them (to a degree) for your own purposes. It spurred me to buy three other Greene books. Highly recommend, at the very least so you can become aware of how power manifests itself.
postDate: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on May 18, 2020

reviewBody: I had it recommended from tiktok. I believe it is a powerful book but please be careful to not fall too deep and don’t use it too much. It can really absorb you and change good values to bad. I use to learn how to know if someone is manipulating me. Please use it for good deeds.
postDate: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on December 28, 2020

name: M. T. Stapleton
reviewTitles: An insightful journey into the lessons of Sun Tzu and Machiavelli (without dark satire)
reviewBody: Although Machiavelli intended for The Prince to be a sarcastic commentary on the lives of courtiers it has been used by many to be a handbook of political manipulation. The 48 Laws of Power enables the lessons without the sarcasm, but at least with the comment that the lessons can be used for any purpose, good or evil, and that in the human condition we are caught up in a potentially deadly game with those who would use this kind of knowledge for selfish purposes. So in the end, we are either players or we (and our friends and families) are victims. We might as well be players and have some chance of not being victims, or perhaps even have some chance of making more of a positive difference in the world. The lessons are given with enlightening examples of consequences of either ignoring the rules or applying the rules, and sometimes also inverting the rules to our advantage. Well written, entertaining, and well worth the cost.
postDate: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on December 23, 2013

name: Sal watson
reviewBody: I've read this book well over dozen times. I apply a lot of the tactics on my job. I've learned how to deal with many situations more strategically.

name: none
reviewBody: This way of thinking and manipulating people is outdated. It creates Narcissism , not true leadership. The laws presented may work temporarily, but eventually others will feel the manipulation and mistrust. This book is dangerous for young readers who are looking for ways to rise to power artificially. The rise to power is based on talent and discipline. Not manipulation. This book will only appeal to those who lack these traits.

name: Treasuretrove96
reviewTitles: Great Strategies On How To Navigate Life
reviewBody: I'm halfway through the book. If you choose to follow the rules with people you interact with on a daily basis, then just remember, it's lonely at the top. I'm using this book in order to not repeat history; To be able to detect and avoid certain people in life. You're able to use this book for good personal gain and not malicious intent. It all depends on how you view it and your purpose for reading it.
postDate: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on August 7, 2020

name: Miles Benate Tyson
reviewTitles: Enjoyable read despite some dark undertones+lots to memorize but not a lot to remember!
reviewBody: Reading this book was fun, although sometimes it made me feel like a bad person. Some sentences are written like "and then your unsuspecting sheeplike victim will never see it coming"...and for me that sort of language is a bit extreme. Why must power be equated with evil? Anyhow, I especially enjoyed the historical examples Greene uses to support his ideas. In terms of content, I cannot at the moment name more than two or three laws of power and their application. Now, I read this a few months ago, and few of the lessons seemed to stick with me. Maybe that's because there are 48 laws to memorize, or perhaps only a few jumped out at me. All in all, I liked the book, and internalized several of these laws of power.
postDate: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on November 22, 2016

reviewBody: I’ve heard a lot about this book and all good things. Finally purchased after years of considering and I should not have waited so long. Lots of great perspective and useful tactics. Not all are agreeable but feel free to pick and choose what suits you. Definitely enjoying the read.
